docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A New Health Plan May Raise Expenses for Sickest Workers'' (front page, Dec. 5): You report that the big insurers' ''new kind of health plan'' will be less costly for employers, but workers who have the bad luck to get seriously ill or injured will have to pay substantially more.

headline.main: A Health Maze: Which Way Out?

docs.abstract: Letter from John Glasel (Health Care for All, New Jersey) deplores new kind of health plan being introduced by insurers (Dec 5 article) and says US needs universal health system financed by more equitable taxation; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: Although the 1996 welfare law set a five-year limit for benefits, the economy is in recession at the very time the benefits are set to end, and many states are setting the deadlines aside for more and more recipients. The law was intended to get people off welfare and into jobs. But for some people in communities with chronic unemployment, relaxed deadlines mean that welfare remains as they have always known it. And advocates for the poor say the safety net of welfare checks for families with children under 18, food stamps, disability insurance and Medicaid insurance looks stronger than they feared when Congress enacted the law.

headline.main: Recession Is Stretching the Limit on Welfare Benefits

docs.abstract: Many states are allowing more and more people to continue on welfare beyond five-year limit set by Congress in 1996 because deadline has arrived during period of recession and rising unemployment; advocates for poor say safety net of welfare checks for families with children under 18, food stamps, disability insurance and Medicaid insurance looks stronger than they feared when Congress enacted law; graph (M)

keywords.value: WORKFARE AND EMPLOYMENT OF WELFARE RECIPIENTS

docs.lead_paragraph: PRUDENTIAL INSURANCE, one of the best-known names in life insurance, plans to sell 110 million shares this week in the biggest initial public offering since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But because the market for new issues remains unsettled, and because Prudential's profits compare unfavorably with those of its competitors, many analysts expect the company to set a modest price for the shares, perhaps $27.50 each on Wednesday. That would be about 85 percent of Prudential's book value, while its rival for leadership in the American life insurance business, MetLife, is trading at 1.4 times book value. The comparable multiple for John Hancock, another major insurer, is 2.14.

headline.main: Investing; Prudential Is Set to Take the Plunge

docs.abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America, now Prudential Financial, plans to sell 110 million shares in biggest initial public offering since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; modest price is expected for offering in view of unsettled market for new stock issues and fact that company's earnings compare unfavorably with those of its competitors; analysts sill say Prudential has considerable appeal; photo; table (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A bitter, weeklong strike by the teachers' union in Middletown ended abruptly this morning as teachers agreed to honor a court back-to-work order and return to their classrooms on Monday morning without a new contract. Immediately afterward, a state judge here ordered the release of about 225 teachers, secretaries and other union members sent to the county jail since Monday for staging an illegal strike.

headline.main: In Middletown, A Strike Ends Without a Deal For Teachers

docs.abstract: Bitter weeklong strike by teacher's union in Middletown, NJ, ends abruptly as teachers agree to honor court back-to-back work order and return to their classrooms without contract; about 225 teachers, secretaries and other union members are ordered released from jail where they were being held for staging illegal strike (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. ERIC B. EVANS A Gardener With Standards He was gorgeous. That much everybody agreed on. But beneath his model's good looks, there were two different Eric B. Evanses. His parents, Charles and Corinne Evans, said he was reserved and quiet, a good student who had been a defensive lineman in high school, and who at 31 was determined to succeed in business.
